intro: Quercus romanica, commonly known as the Roman oak, is a species of flowering plant in the beech family, Fagaceae. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 15–25 meters, characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in the autumn. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Native to the Mediterranean region, it thrives in well-drained soils and full sunlight. Its hardy nature makes it a valuable ornamental and ecological plant in suitable climates.
